phrase.item: Daily News
March 15: the Russian people have forced the abdication of their emporer, who hitherto had dictated the course of the nation, having fought him in their bid to become a republic.

word.item: they have them as a president

phrase.item: The fighting at least has ceased, and the country is becoming a republic with a president, just as the United States elects their president.

March 16: the emporer having been deposed by the revolution the next in line for the Russian throne, the Grand Duke, has immediately quit his duties, himself sharing the belief that the nation should become a republic.
Therefore Russia will henceforth be a republic, and will go on to elect a president.
March 20: French forces have shown their might and driven back the Germans by 25 miles, and the British have captured some 40 villages.
German soldiers routinely destroyed houses, fuel, and farms as they were forced to retreat.
They do this in order to deny it to the British and French.
March 25: a decision has been that armed men should henceforth guard fuel supplies, railroad ties, and large timber, day and night across the United States.
March 27: Congress has decreed that immigrants coming to live in the United States from different nations must be literate.
No matter the nation, they should be able to read the Bible, as translations have now been made in every country.
Therefore, the decision was made in Congress to test immigrants arriving from other countries to live in the United States on their ability to read the Bible, in order to know if they are literate.
March 26: on this day British soldiers engaged in a mighty battle with Turkish forces.
The fighting took place in the Holy Land, Palestine. The British have been laying railroad as they make their way from Egypt to the Holy Land.
Turkish soldiers numbered 20,000 but they were driven back, and 900 were taken captive.
A great military leader was among those taken captive.
Therefore the British declared victory.
April 5: in Redding, California, Lassen Peak has erupted and dangerous storms of ash are reported on account of the smoke that is said to be discharging from the blaze inside.

word.item: he told them to think about it

phrase.item: April 6: in Washington, members of Congress have debated and cast their ballots after President Wilson asked them to consider whether or not to join the war.
There were 373 yeas for 50 nays, and therefore the United States has decided to go to war against Germany, and President WIlson has now signed the resolution.
April 9: on this day an earthquake struck St. Louis for eight minutes, though it was not very strong.
Some {watch towers} and {fireplaces} were torn apart.
This is now the third earthquake to strike the community; there was one long ago in 1811, and again in 1812, and finally it has happened again.
April 11: the brightest minds from will be meeting in Washington presently on account of the the Great War.

President Wilson will be discussing many things concerning the war with Arthur J. Balfour, a prominent and wise man from the British government, and M. Viviani, likewise a notable wise man from France, who will arrive in Washington D.C. for the meeting.
April 22: Arthur J. Balfour, one of the most respected men in Britain, arrived on this day in Washington.
They will be meeting with President Wilson and other leaders on account of the war. They will be exploring how to bring the Great War to a close and restore peace among nations.

April 24: René Viviani and Marshal Joffre, some of the most prominent men in France, have arrived in Fortress Monroe, VA from their country and are heading for Washington where President Wilson will meet them for a most important meeting.
Never before has such a meeting been held between such prominent leaders of nations.
